{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-099-05-A |Item_parent=Migraine, trigeminal neuralgia and facial pain |Item_parent_short=Migraine, trigeminal neuralgia and facial pain |Rank=A |Title=Conducting the interview and gathering evidence for the diagnosis of vascular facial pain |Description=Know the positive clinical elements that allow the diagnosis to be made |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=5}} - '''Algie vasculaire de la face (AVF)''' : leader of the ''[[Céphalée SD-118|céphalées]] trigémino-autonomiques''' (CTA) = strict unilateral character of the pain and presence of dysautonomic signs. - AVF seizures: strictly unilateral periorbital seizures, very intense but short < 3 hours, with trigemino-autonomic symptoms and characteristic motor agitation. - Migraine-like" signs, [[Nausea SD-012|nausea]]/[[Vomiting SD-013|vomiting]], photo and phonophobia often present, should not mislead the diagnosis. - Attacks occur daily, but more often than not at different times of the year.
*''Episodic AVF'': in 90% of patients, attacks occur for periods of a few weeks to a few months. There is sometimes a circadian cycle (seizures occur at fixed times, especially at night) and a circannual cycle (in the same season), as well as a link with alcohol consumption.
*'''Chronic AVF''': in 10% of cases, attacks recur over the long term with no remission of more than three; this is then chronic AVF, a fearsome disease burdened with significant psychiatric comorbidity: depressive signs, agoraphobia and suicidal tendencies.
{| class="wikitable" | colspan="2" |'''Table. ICHD3 diagnostic criteria for facial vascular pain.''' |- |A |At least five attacks meeting criteria B-D |- |B |Severe to very severe unilateral orbital, supraorbital and/or temporal pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes (untreated) |- |C |One or both of the following: 1. at least one of the following signs/symptoms on the same side as the pain a) conjunctival injection and/or lacrimation b) nasal congestion and/or rhinorrhoea c) palpebral oedema d) sweating of the forehead and/or face e) miosis and/or ptosis 2. an impression of impatience or restlessness |- |D |Seizure frequency = 1 every 2 days to 8/day in active period |- |E |Not best explained by another ICHD-3 diagnosis |}

question.title: What is a characteristic of Algie vasculaire de la face (AVF) seizures?
question.description: A multiple-choice question about the diagnostic criteria for vascular facial pain

option_a.title: Seizures occur only at night
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect option that might be tempting for someone who doesn't read carefully

option_b.title: Seizures last for more than 3 hours
option_b.description: A plausible but incorrect option that might be tempting for someone who doesn't read carefully

option_c.title: Seizures occur daily, but more often than not at different times of the year
option_c.description: The correct option, consistent with the text

option_d.title: Seizures are always accompanied by nausea and vomiting
option_d.description: A plausible but incorrect option that might be tempting for someone who doesn't read carefully
